definition[0]: the movement of money coming into a business as income and going out as wages, materials etc
example[0]: We expect a rise in both our production and our cash flow.
example[1]: The builder is unable to pay due to cash flow problems.
definition[1]: the amounts of money coming into and going out of a company, and the timing of these
example[2]: the lack of cash flow that results from customers not paying bills on time
example[3]: The business is suffering severe cash flow problems.
example[4]: He will have to keep to a business plan with strict month-by-month cash flow projections.
definition[2]: profit made by a business in a particular period of time, measured in different ways by different businesses
example[5]: Time Warner defines cash flow as earnings before interest payments, taxes and depreciation.
example[6]: Volvo needs to raise production to 500,000 units to generate the cash flow (=to produce it) required for expensive new model development programmes.
example[7]: The company announced an increase in its after-tax cash flow.
